I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Republic of Indonesia for the State Accountability Revitalization Project.1  
 
2.  The project aims to support key government reform priorities to improve government 
accountability by increasing the capacity of central and regional internal auditors and public 
finance officers. It focuses on (i) providing incentives to auditors and finance officers to improve 
their capacity, (ii) improving trainer capacity, and (iii) implementing the e-learning and state 
accountability management information system (SIMA). This will improve governance in public 
financial management (PFM) and public service delivery for the benefit of Indonesian citizens. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
3.   Over the last decade, the government has placed a high priority on strengthening 
governance in public sector management and public service delivery. The Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) risk assessment for Indonesia shows the government made considerable progress 
with the legal and regulatory framework for PFM. In particular, most implementing regulations 
supporting the main PFM laws, i.e., laws on state finance, treasury, and audit, have been 
promulgated.  Transparency,  accountability,  and  efficiency  are  key  pillars  of  PFM  and 
procurement-related  reforms.  This  reflects  the  government’s  priority  to  build  effective  and 
accountable  institutions  to  use  available  resources  to  translate  into  more  effective 
development.2 The country’s effectiveness in providing goods and services has been improving. 
Most notably in 2009, for the first time, the Supreme Audit Board (BPK) gave a qualified (clean 
with exceptions) 3 opinion on the government’s financial statement, as opposed to a previous 
disclaimer. Furthermore, about 40% of the line ministries and agencies received an unqualified 
opinion.  
 
4.   To maintain momentum, the government has set an ambitious target for achieving 
unqualified audit opinions for all central government agencies by 2014. Progress has been 
made, particularly in the area of budget execution, with the development of a treasury single 
account  to  strengthen  the  comprehensiveness  and  control  over  spending  and  cash 
management. Improvements were also made in fiscal accounts, accounting practices, payroll 
and internal controls, and fiscal risk management. However, some indicators remain behind 
comparator economies in Southeast Asia.4 Further improvements are needed to achieve good 
governance  to  improve  the  quality  of  services  to  the  population, i.e.,  economical,  speedy, 
transparent,  and  accountable  as  defined  in  Indonesia’s  long-term  development  plan.5 The 
government  has  implemented  the  control  framework  of  the  Committee  of  Sponsoring 
Organizations and strengthened the government’s internal audit function.

5.  Despite significant progress, ADB’s sector assessment on public sector management in 
Indonesia  identifies  lack  of  adequate  capacity  in  public  audit  institutions,  especially  local 
institutions, which negatively affects the performance of the government’s audit institutions.6 
Coordination among regional agencies is weak, and no uniform audit planning framework is in 
place. Although the government regulation (PP) 60/2008 clarified the delineation of external and 
internal audit functions, audit institutions, particularly regional internal auditors, have insufficient 
capacity. The regulation requires all government institutions, including local governments, to 
implement the Government Internal Control System (GICS). Under the regulation, the Central 
Government Internal Auditors (BPKP) is mandated to ensure the quality of internal audit reports 
and to provide guidance and consultancy on the GICS. Thus, the capacity of internal auditors 
needs to be improved through formal education and a professional certification program. In 
addition,  government  officials  involved  in  financial  management,  budgeting,  planning,  and 
financial reporting require capacity development to ensure that auditors and auditees have 
common knowledge and standards. The quality of audit by inspectors general in line ministries 
and local government inspectorates remains substandard with little focus on risk-based audit. A 
recent mapping process on the capacity of the government internal audit function in Indonesia, 
based on the internal audit capability model developed by the Institute of Internal Auditors, 
revealed  that  93%  of  the  respondents  (25  inspectors  general  and  237  local  government 
inspectorates)  reported  that  (i) transactional  audits  were  conducted  for  accuracy  and 
compliance only, (ii) audit plans were not prepared based on stakeholder priorities, and (iii) audit 
output was based on the capacity of certain individuals. 
 
6.  The  country’s  decentralization  process  (starting  in  2000)  transferred  more  than  30 
functions and 2 million civil servants from the central to subnational governments. However, the 
new intergovernment setting inherited a large administrative and institutional burden, a multitude 
of public agencies, lack of professional civil servants, uncertified accountants, weak public 
management  systems,  graft,  and  corruption.  The  latest  data  of  the  State  Ministry  for 
Administrative Reforms (2008) shows that 50% of Indonesia's 4 million civil servants were not 
sufficiently qualified. Latest data from BPKP shows that Papua and West Papua provinces have 
no  government  internal  auditors.  Lack  of  capacity  limits  effective  PFM  and  influences 
governance  by  regional  governments.  In  2010,  only  7%  of  the  516  regional  governments 
received an unqualified (clean without exceptions) audit opinion for their financial statements. 
 
7.  Other factors weaken regional PFM. First, decentralization resulted in more civil servants 
in regional governments, which translated into more of the budget being spent on salaries, thus 
decreasing available funds for better service delivery and capacity building. Second, regional 
governments are seeking ways to expand income sources, i.e., taxes and levies, which in some 
cases (due to low capacity in formulating revenue policies) have become a burden to citizens 
and business. Third, central government PFM-related laws and regulations are often complex 
and inconsistent.  
 
8.  Strategic policy and sector relevance. The project is in line with the government’s 
plan to promote good national and local governance. The government’s National Medium-Term 
Development Plan (RPJMN), 2010–2014 identifies good governance as a priority. This priority 
intersects with ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2012–2014 for Indonesia,7 which identifies 
improved governance as essential for more inclusive growth, especially in the context of PFM 
and decentralization. The project is in line with ADB’s existing support for local government 
systems and capacity building in PFM under ADB’s Second Local Government Finance and 
                                                 
6  Sector Assessment: Public Sector Management (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).  
7  ADB. 2012. Country Partnership Strategy: Indonesia, 2012–2014. Manila.

3 
Governance  Reform  Program  (LGFGR). 8  The  project  targets  capacity  development  for 
decentralized public management to improve governance; financial management systems of 
local  governments;  and  national  and  local  audit  systems,  and  capacity  for  planning, 
policymaking, and financial management. This target supports BPKP’s 2010–2014 strategic 
plans to strengthen PFM officer capacity to become professional and competent. They aim to 
have 2,500 internal auditors at central and regional governments. 
 
9.  Lessons from ADB support for public sector management. The project’s design 
builds on progress and lessons from three ADB programs: the State Audit Reform Sector 
Development  Program,9 the  LGFGR  Sector  Development  Program,10 and  the  Sustainable 
Capacity Building for Decentralization Project.11 They show capacity building to be the key 
component to implementing good governance practice in the government. In particular, focus 
should  be  given  to  building  the  PFM  capacity  of  local  government  staff.  Incorporating 
information, and communication technology in the business processes of local governments 
improves efficiency and increases their accountability. 
 
10.  Aid coordination. In the design of the project, ADB coordinated with other development 
partners, such as the Australian Agency for International Development, United States Agency 
for International Development, and the World Bank. The World Bank, in particular, is managing 
a multidonor trust fund on PFM, funded by the governments of Switzerland and the Netherlands, 
and the European Union.12 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The  impact  will  be  strengthened  accountability  of  central  and  local  government 
institutions to deliver high-quality public services. The outcome will be strengthened capacity of 
the government’s internal auditors and public finance officers to plan budgets, report, carry out 
internal audits, and manage assets. 
 
C.  Outputs 
1.  Output 1: Capacity Development for Government Internal Auditors and 
Public Finance Officers  
12.  To meet the minimum standard central and regional competency requirements, the 
project will provide financial resources for degree programs and certification for the current 
internal auditors and PFM officers. The degree program will support an estimated 2,500 internal 
auditors and finance officers in obtaining graduate degrees in government accounting and 
public finance. To ensure transparent and accountable selection, rigorous methodology based 
on  objective  and  transparent  eligibility  criteria  for  the  universities  and  participants  will  be

13.  The project will finance specialized courses, training, and certifications for an estimated 
9,800 government internal auditors and finance officers of public institutions in central and 
regional governments, across provinces, districts, and cities. Certifying government internal 
auditors and PFM officers ensures GICS competencies. BPKP, through its regulation 211/2010, 
establishes a competency standard or minimum requirement for auditors as a quality assurance 
tool for government internal auditors. The standards include minimum competency requirements 
for  risk  management,  strategic  audit,  audit  reporting,  professional  attitude  in  audit, 
communication, public sector management, and audit management. BPKP’s target for 2014 is 
that all government internal auditors will comply with the competency standard. The training will 
cover PFM transactions in planning, budgeting, accounting, procurement, public debt, asset 
management, ethics, and financial reporting. It will also cover training to support implementation 
of  the  GICS  and  state  budget  accounting  and  Presidential  Instruction  (Inpres)  No.4/2011, 
Acceleration in Quality Improvement of State Finance Accountability. Certification programs will 
include the mandatory auditor functional position (Jabatan Fungsional Auditor [JFA]).  
 
14.  Cooperation between BPKP and regional governments. The project will seek to 
increase  cooperation  between  BPKP  and  regional  governments  through  the  transfer  of 
knowledge  from  BPKP  as  the  central  government  internal  auditor  to  regional  government 
internal auditors. This will include active participation of the BPKP training facility and BPKP 
establishing centers of excellence of internal audit in selected regional universities. The transfer 
of knowledge will entail BPKP auditors to develop internal audit cooperation with selected 
regional governments and internal audit curriculum in local universities. The establishment of 
the center of excellence in selected regional universities will promote (i) internal audit best 
practices  and  (ii)  cooperation  between  regional  universities  in  providing  PFM  courses.  In 
particular, the project will look into promoting a twinning program between more- and less-
developed regional universities. 
 
15.  Training  of  trainers.  The  project  will  enhance  the  technical  and  training  skills  of  
200  potential  internal  audit  trainers  from  BPKP  and  14  leading  regional  universities  by 
examining best practice in the full spectrum of internal audit functions. The training will include 
(i) internal audit risk assessment process; (ii) setting of audit objectives and development of an 
audit plan; (iii) selection of a sample of representative contracts for audit; (iv) audit execution; (v) 
assessment of value for money; (vi) analysis of audit observations and findings, and discussion 
with BPKP; (vii) audit reporting; and (viii) improvement of the training methodology. Topics such 
as  procurement  audit  and  contract  management  will  be  included.  The  project  will  instill 
international best practices for the trainers. BPKP will play an active role by providing resource 
speakers to ensure that trainers have hands-on experience. 
 
2.  Output 2: Development of e-Learning System and Modules  
16.  The project will develop an e-learning system and module for training and certifying 
government internal auditors. Full implementation of the GICS will require 40,000 JFA-certified 
internal auditors in central and local government inspectorates. The current annual capacity of 
conventional JFA training in BPKP is about 2,000 participants. The project will use an e-learning 
system as an innovative means to reach the target of 40,000. The project-funded e-learning 
system will encompass various forms of e-learning and e-teaching, and may include web and/or 
computer-based training, virtual classroom opportunities, and digital collaboration. The project 
will provide funds to design the best system suitable for BPKP’s needs to provide GICS training

5 
to all government internal supervisory officials. The modules will be consistent and in equal 
quality as provided in the regular JFA classroom training, thus ensuring quality assurance of the 
graduates. To ensure smooth implementation of the system, it will be tested, piloted, and rolled 
out on a trial basis before being fully implemented. Post project use of the e-learning system is 
crucial to meet the demand for JFA-certified auditors, and therefore, ADB will ensure that BPKP 
allocates funding to continue use of the system under its national training and education center. 
 
3.  Output 3: Institutional Strengthening through System Improvement 
17.  State accountability management information system. The project will assist BPKP 
in  developing  an  integrated  SIMA  as  part  of  BPKP  infrastructure  strengthening.  Capacity 
building for government PFM officers is expected to improve governance, particularly the quality 
of institution’s financial statements or reports. With its new mandate, BPKP is in charge of 
ensuring  quality  assurance  for  the  government’s  financial  statements,  and  providing 
consultations to stakeholders. The government institutions provide their financial reports to 
BPKP for quality assurance prior to submitting to BPK. The SIMA will enable BPKP to receive 
high-quality reports, and at the output end, provide accurate analysis and information to its 
stakeholders. The SIMA is expected to support BPKP’s accessibility to the reports, and help it 
produce quality and timely analysis for its stakeholders.  
 
18.  SIMA development will consider existing systems, business process improvement and 
change management, and communication with stakeholders. The project funding will be used to 
design, install, and roll out the system on a trial basis, as well as provide necessary training, and 
software development and licenses. The project will undertake consultations and workshops on 
change management with the stakeholders to ensure smooth system implementation. 
 
19.  Cross-sector evaluation system. The project will assist BPKP in piloting an evaluation 
system  for  cross-sector  programs  based  on  government  regulation  (PP)  60/2008,  which 
redefined BPKP’s role as the President of Indonesia’s auditors or the government internal 
auditors.13 As such, BPKP is mandated to conduct internal supervision or evaluation of state 
financial  accountability  over  certain  activities,  including  the  government’s  cross-sector 
programs. BPKP will conduct the evaluation and make recommendations to the President. As 
this  authority  is  new  to  BPKP  and  in  line  with  the  project’s  objective  to  improve  good 
governance in PFM, the project will support BPKP to develop standard audit procedures and 
execute its authority. The project will select specific cross-sector programs on a pilot basis. The 
SIMA is expected to support an evaluation system for cross-sector programs. Thus, through this 
pilot testing, the SIMA will be used to ensure its operationalization and any feedback will be 
used to improve the system.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
23.  BPKP will be the executing agency. The project will be implemented over 5 years from 
January 2013 to December 2017. As mandated in PP 60/2008, Inpres 4/2011, and RPJMN 
2010–2014, BPKP is the coordinator for the GICS implementation.

7 
24.  The project will help BPKP develop modules for training and certification, taking into 
account existing training manuals on state budget accounting, and internal audit as references. 
BPKP will coordinate with the Ministry of Home Affairs (MOHA) and MOF in conducting training 
and developing training materials for public finance officers. This coordination is imperative to 
encompass training already provided by MOF’s directorate generals of fiscal balance and of 
treasury  on  regional  financial  management  and  on  budgeting  (also  provided  by  MOHA’s 
Directorate General of Regional Finance). In addition to the development of training manuals, 
coordination will focus on utilizing the information system for regional finance management. The 
regional financial information system will be viewed as a tool to improve financial management 
of regional governments nationwide, while the main objective still focuses on increasing the 
capacity of personnel who manage financial planning, budgeting, reporting, and auditing. 
 
25.  The project will help BPKP conduct the regional training and certification program, which 
will utilize BPKP’s 25 representative offices across Indonesia and regional universities. The 
regional  offices  will  be  the  training  centers  for  the  region’s  PFM  officers.  BPKP’s  existing 
memorandums of understandings with local universities will support the training activities.  
 
26.  BPKP will be responsible for project planning, implementation, financial management, 
procurement, information dissemination, and reporting. It will set up a project management unit 
with the head of BPKP’s bureau for audit planning as project director to provide oversight. The 
BPKP  project  manager  will  assist  the  project  director  with  day-to-day  management  of  the 
project. A project implementation unit will be set up in each BPKP regional office.   The  project 
will form a steering committee to provide overall policy guidance, and monitor, supervise, and 
evaluate project outcomes. The committee will also provide guidance on the selection criteria for 
the degree program candidates and criteria for participating universities. BPKP will chair the 
committee,  which  will  comprise  directors  from  BPKP,  MOF,  MOHA  and  the  National 
Development Planning Agency (BAPPENAS). The project will develop effective and efficient 
monitoring covering all provinces, districts, and cities to ensure timely implementation, while 
maintaining high quality standards for the program. The  implementation  arrangements  are 
summarized in Table 3 and described in detail in the project administration manual.14  
 
27.  Assisted by consultants financed under the project, BPKP will develop rigorous selection 
methodology  for  the  universities  participating  in  the  degree  program  (output  1)  to  provide 
objective and transparent eligibility criteria, including (i) a university with a master’s degree 
(graduate) study program in accounting or public finance registered with the Directorate General 
of Higher Education of the Ministry of Education and Culture; and (ii) such study program has at 
least a “B” accreditation from the National Accreditation Agency for Higher Education. The 
university eligibility criteria will be agreed with ADB. Further, BPKP guided by the steering 
committee, and based on equitable and transparent criteria will select relevant government 
officers as candidates to participate in the study program. The project will develop the criteria 
using the government’s criteria for the master’s degree government scholarship program as a 
standard. The list of selected participants will be published and periodically updated. For cost 
efficiency, a participating student will enroll in the eligible university located in the vicinity of the 
student’s residence. If and when selected participants are in proximity to a university that meets 
the agreed eligibility criteria, the university will be engaged through single-source selection 
under service delivery assignment (education) contracts to provide specialized degree courses 
to the selected participants. The project administration manual identifies candidate universities.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Technical  
28.  The project provides significant technical improvements through the use of accountability 
and e-learning systems based on information and communication technology in BPKP. An 
assessment of technical viability will be conducted during system design. It will review available 
infrastructure, technology, and compatibility with local conditions prior to system installation, 
taking into account other ADB-funded e-learning projects in other countries. Local staff capacity 
will be evaluated for system operation and maintenance, and upgraded as needed. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
29.  The economic rationale for the project rests largely on promoting good governance 
through stronger capacity of internal auditors and public finance officers. Good governance will 
provide efficient and effective use of state funds for development to benefit the nation. Budget 
leakages across governments in the country are expected to be reduced through improved 
competency of government internal auditors and public finance officers. Improved governance 
and transparency will improve investor confidence. 
 
C.  Governance 
30.  BPKP has sufficient capacity, staffing, and systems in place for financial, accounting, 
and procurement functions. As the government’s internal auditors, BPKP has extensive financial 
management  capacity,  and  is  responsible  for  setting  benchmarks  for  good  financial 
management to other government bodies. All BPKP staff hold the minimum of a diploma in 
accounting from the State Accounting Institute. Based on its experience in implementing the 
ADB-funded State Audit Reform Sector Development Program, BPKP is expected to have the 
capacity  to  manage  project  implementation,  financial  management,  and  procurement  in

9 
accordance with ADB guidelines and requirements. Thus, management control of the project 
can be relied upon. Some new staff unfamiliar with ADB procedures will be provided with 
training on ADB project management, administration, procurement, and disbursement.  
 
31.  Due diligence to ensure sound selection of candidates for the degree program and 
participating universities covered under the project is required to achieve the project objectives. 
In coordination with the Ministry of Education and Culture, the project’s steering committee will 
issue and implement transparent guidelines on criteria for selecting candidates and universities 
to participate in the degree program to ensure program quality. The guidelines will include 
selection procedures and mechanisms to implement the program. 
 
32.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government and BPKP. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures 
are described in the project administration manual.15  
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
33.  The  project  will  support  Indonesia’s  poverty  reduction  goals  through  improved 
accountability of public institutions in managing state funds. This improvement will enhance 
public confidence in the government and therefore enhance the effectiveness and efficiency of 
delivering basic public services to the poor.  Regional disparities in terms of poverty rates and 
access to basic services continue. In 2010, Maluku province reported a poverty rate of 27.7%, 
compared  with  3.5%  in  Jakarta  and  4.3%  in  Bali.  Inequalities  extend  to  other  human 
development dimensions. East Maluku reported a human development index16 of 70.96 in 2009, 
well  below  77.36  for  Jakarta.  The  percentage  of  households  with  improved  sanitation  in 
Yogyakarta is more than 75%, compared with around 25% in Papua and Kalimantan Tengah. At 
least 12 provinces report that fewer than 70% of households have access to electricity; about 12 
provinces  report  almost  full  coverage.  Progress  in  reducing  poverty  and  achieving  the 
Millennium Development Goals will largely depend on improved access to, and quality of, basic 
services delivered to the local population. In supporting it, increased efforts are needed to 
accelerate development in lagging regions, strengthen pro-poor elements of regional budgets, 
and improve public financial systems and governance. 
 
34.  The project has some gender elements because it will directly improve women's access 
to capacity and career development through education and training programs supported by the 
project. At start-up, the project will collect and determine sex-disaggregated baseline data for all 
participating regional governments and the central government. The project will ensure that at 
least 30% of participants under output 1 are women. The project will include sex-disaggregated 
data in the monitoring and evaluation system to ensure the female representation target is 
achieved at project completion.  
  
E.  Safeguards 
35.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project is classified 
under category C for impacts on the environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous

peoples. The project will involve capacity building activities. Hence, no adverse environmental 
impacts are expected. Land acquisition and resettlement is not expected because the project 
will take place in existing government offices and/or university premises. The project is not 
expected to affect indigenous peoples.  
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
36.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4 and described in detail 
in the risk assessment and risk management plan.17

IV.  ASSURANCES  
37.  The government has assured ADB that implementation of the project will conform to all 
applicable  ADB  policies  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures,  safeguards, 
gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail in the project 
administration manual and loan documents. 
 
38.  The government has agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, which are 
set forth in the loan agreement.  
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
39.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  of 
$57,750,000 to the Republic of Indonesia for the State Accountability Revitalization Project, 
from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, with interest to be determined in accordance with ADB’s 
London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; for a term of 18 years, including a 
grace period of 6 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance 
with those set forth in the draft loan agreement presented to the Board.
